quotes.topic_title: Fuel and engine framing for marketing
quotes.text: Forget the product marketing content partner, demand and growth, forget all of it, and just think of marketing as you need a fuel and you need an engine.
quotes.speaker: Emily Kramer
quotes.context: A simplifying mental model that cuts through marketing org complexity by reducing it to two core components.

quotes.topic_title: Fuel and engine framing for marketing
quotes.text: And goal is like all the things that you're creating. I mean this should be obvious, but it's the content, it's the word, it's the design in some regard. All the things that you're making, all the things that are going to add value.
quotes.speaker: Emily Kramer
quotes.context: Defines “fuel” concretely so teams can inventory what they’re producing and assess whether it’s truly value-adding.

quotes.topic_title: Fuel and engine framing for marketing
quotes.text: An engine is how you get it out to the right people. And all of the tracking of that and sort of the ops work I put under engine, everyone needs an engine.
quotes.speaker: Emily Kramer
quotes.context: Clarifies that distribution plus measurement/ops are part of the same “engine,” emphasizing the necessity of operational rigor.

quotes.topic_title: Fuel and engine framing for marketing
quotes.text: And the question is, where do you have the biggest challenge right now? Or where do you think if you did more, you would grow faster? Is it on fuel side or is on the engine side?
quotes.speaker: Emily Kramer
quotes.context: A practical diagnostic to identify the current growth constraint and prioritize investment between creation and distribution.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: In our chat, Emily shares a ton of concrete advice on what to look for in your first marketing hire, what the different archetypes of marketers are, and who you should look for based on your business model.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a practical hiring framework (first marketing hire + marketer archetypes) tied to business model fit.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: How to work with marketing effectively as a product team, and also what red flags to look for that tell you that your marketing team is not doing a great job.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Points to actionable guidance for product–marketing collaboration and diagnostic signals of marketing underperformance.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: And the best compliment that I can give her is that she's a marketer that thinks like a product manager.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Memorable mental model for effective marketing: adopting product-manager-style thinking.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Emily is super specific and incredibly concrete with her advice, including sharing a ton of templates that you can immediately use that we link to in the share rooms.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Emphasizes immediately usable, template-driven methodology rather than abstract marketing theory.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor: Amplitude product loop and new tools
quotes.text: Well, we've always thought of Amplitude as being about supporting the full product loop. Think collect data, inform that, ship experiments and learn.
quotes.speaker: John Cutler
quotes.context: A concise framework for building a growth system around a closed-loop cycle of data, decisions, experimentation, and learning.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor: Amplitude product loop and new tools
quotes.text: That's the heart of growth to us.
quotes.speaker: John Cutler
quotes.context: A memorable definition that reframes growth as an iterative learning loop rather than a set of isolated tactics.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor: Amplitude product loop and new tools
quotes.text: So the big aha was seeing how many customers were using Amplitude to analyze experiments, use segments for outreach and send data to other destinations.
quotes.speaker: John Cutler
quotes.context: A practical product-expansion heuristic: watch what customers already do with your tool to identify adjacent offerings.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor: Amplitude product loop and new tools
quotes.text: Experiment in CDP came out of listening to and observing our customers.
quotes.speaker: John Cutler
quotes.context: A clear methodology for roadmap decisions—derive new products from observed customer workflows rather than internal assumptions.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor: Amplitude product loop and new tools
quotes.text: Amplitude tries to meet customers where they are.
quotes.speaker: John Cutler
quotes.context: A customer-centric positioning principle that guides packaging, onboarding, and product surface area decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor: Lenny’s Jobs talent marketplace
quotes.text: Thousands of people apply to join this collective and I personally review and accept just about 10% of them.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a concrete, high-selectivity vetting process (10% acceptance) that signals candidate quality to hiring managers.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor: Lenny’s Jobs talent marketplace
quotes.text: If you're a hiring manager, you can sign up and get access to hundreds of hand curated people who are open to new opportunities.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Actionable recruiting advice: use a curated marketplace to quickly reach pre-vetted, actively open candidates.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor: Lenny’s Jobs talent marketplace
quotes.text: It's free, you can be anonymous and you can even hide yourself from specific companies.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Offers a candidate-side tactic for exploring opportunities with privacy controls, reducing the risk of being discovered by current or undesired employers.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor: Lenny’s Jobs talent marketplace
quotes.text: Join almost 100 other companies who are actively hiring through this collective.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Provides social proof and a specific adoption data point that can influence a hiring manager’s decision to try the marketplace.

quotes.topic_title: Emily’s career overview and MKT1 plug
quotes.text: And theme of my career has been building out marketing teams at B2B startups.
quotes.speaker: Emily Kramer
quotes.context: Sets a clear practitioner-focused throughline: specializing in building marketing functions inside B2B startups.

quotes.topic_title: Emily’s career overview and MKT1 plug
quotes.text: I was at Ticketfly, I was like the second marketer.
quotes.speaker: Emily Kramer
quotes.context: A concrete example of joining extremely early and helping shape marketing from near-zero.

quotes.topic_title: Emily’s career overview and MKT1 plug
quotes.text: And then I went to Asana where I was the first marketer when they were about 30, 35 people and built up that team and led the team for just under four years.
quotes.speaker: Emily Kramer
quotes.context: Specific stage/scale detail that’s useful for founders benchmarking when to hire the first marketer and what “building the team” can look like.

quotes.topic_title: Emily’s career overview and MKT1 plug
quotes.text: and eventually went to Carta, which was about 300 people when I joined-ish give or take, but didn't have a marketing function at the time.
quotes.speaker: Emily Kramer
quotes.context: Counterintuitive benchmark: even at ~300 people, a company may still lack a formal marketing function—highlighting how variable org maturity can be.

quotes.topic_title: Emily’s career overview and MKT1 plug
quotes.text: So built that function up from scratch. Much like Asana but at a very different stage in the company's life cycle.
quotes.speaker: Emily Kramer
quotes.context: A reusable mental model: “build from scratch” can apply across stages, but the approach must adapt to the company lifecycle.

quotes.topic_title: Common mistakes hiring early marketing roles
quotes.text: So a couple of mistakes that I see is just hiring people that don't cover the area that you need most as a startup.
quotes.speaker: Emily Kramer
quotes.context: Highlights the core early-stage hiring failure mode: misalignment between the hire’s strengths and the startup’s most urgent marketing needs.

quotes.topic_title: Common mistakes hiring early marketing roles
quotes.text: So I see that especially with business model where I think having the right business model experience is almost more important than having industry experience or experience with that audience.
quotes.speaker: Emily Kramer
quotes.context: Counterintuitive hiring heuristic: prioritize business model fit (e.g., PLG vs enterprise) over domain/audience familiarity.

quotes.topic_title: Common mistakes hiring early marketing roles
quotes.text: And my response is you, you're going to really narrow your set up people with that, and also it doesn't matter as much because great marketers learn the audience and learn the product quickly.
quotes.speaker: Emily Kramer
quotes.context: Practical guidance for widening candidate pools and reducing over-indexing on niche industry experience.

quotes.topic_title: Common mistakes hiring early marketing roles
quotes.text: But the business model really dictates what marketing does in a big way.
quotes.speaker: Emily Kramer
quotes.context: A simple mental model for scoping marketing roles and activities based on how the company sells and grows.

quotes.topic_title: Common mistakes hiring early marketing roles
quotes.text: But the first thing I say is forget all the sub-functions that you've heard about in marketing. Forget the product marketing content marketing partner, demand and growth, forget all of it and just think of marketing as you need fuel and you need an engine.
quotes.speaker: Emily Kramer
quotes.context: Memorable framework for founders to simplify marketing org design into inputs (fuel) and a system to convert them (engine).

quotes.topic_title: Fuel vs engine: diagnosing constraints and examples
quotes.text: But the first thing I say is forget all the sub-functions that you've heard about in marketing. Forget the product marketing content marketing partner, demand and growth, forget all of it and just think of marketing as you need fuel and you need an engine.
quotes.speaker: Emily Kramer
quotes.context: A simplifying mental model for diagnosing marketing needs without getting stuck in org-chart subfunctions.

quotes.topic_title: Fuel vs engine: diagnosing constraints and examples
quotes.text: Typically, if you just think about it logically, you kind of need the fuel first. And sometimes what I see is people just build an engine first and they're like why isn't this working we're sending so many outbound emails? And it's like, well you don't have anything valuable to put in those, you have no fuel so this isn't working.
quotes.speaker: Emily Kramer
quotes.context: A counterintuitive warning that scaling distribution (engine) before value/positioning assets (fuel) often fails.

quotes.topic_title: Fuel vs engine: diagnosing constraints and examples
quotes.text: Or you see the flip side where they're making a whole bunch of things, they're writing a bunch of blog quotes or making a bunch of content and they're like, this content doesn't work. It's like, we'll, have you tried distributing it? Because if you're not distributing that and getting mileage out of it's a waste of time.
quotes.speaker: Emily Kramer
quotes.context: A practical diagnostic: if content exists but isn’t getting reach, the constraint is distribution/engine, not creation.

quotes.topic_title: Fuel vs engine: diagnosing constraints and examples
quotes.text: If you have a Slack community that should be tool and engine.
quotes.speaker: Emily Kramer
quotes.context: A concrete example of an initiative that can simultaneously create assets (fuel) and provide distribution (engine).

quotes.topic_title: Fuel vs engine: diagnosing constraints and examples
quotes.text: The email copy itself is fuel, but how you've set up the email and the segmentation you've used and the rules for that drip email, that's the engine.
quotes.speaker: Emily Kramer
quotes.context: A crisp heuristic for separating “what you say” (fuel) from “how it runs/scales” (engine) inside the same channel.

quotes.topic_title: Product marketing definition and three archetypes
quotes.text: But really a product marketer, they understand the product, they understand the audience and they understand the market in which you're operating. And from there they can figure out how to communicate with your audience about the right things at the right time.
quotes.speaker: Emily Kramer
quotes.context: A crisp definition of product marketing that practitioners can use to scope the role and prioritize work around product, audience, and market understanding.

quotes.topic_title: Product marketing definition and three archetypes
quotes.text: And people think they need product marketers. One because it's like a fake people say, but two, because product marketers tend to shadow this line between fuel and engine.
quotes.speaker: Emily Kramer
quotes.context: Challenges default hiring assumptions and introduces the “fuel vs engine” lens for deciding what kind of marketer you actually need.

quotes.topic_title: Product marketing definition and three archetypes
quotes.text: And so sometimes that's a great answer. You need a product marketer, but sometimes you need someone that's scrappier in different areas.
quotes.speaker: Emily Kramer
quotes.context: Practical hiring guidance: the right first marketing hire depends on the company’s immediate growth constraints, not a standard org chart.

quotes.topic_title: Product marketing definition and three archetypes
quotes.text: And then we talk about the three typical subfunction that you would hire, which would be content, community type person, a growth demands and type person and a product marketer.
quotes.speaker: Emily Kramer
quotes.context: A simple early-stage marketing archetype framework to map needs and sequence hires across content/community, growth/demand, and product marketing.

quotes.topic_title: Product marketing definition and three archetypes
quotes.text: But you want someone who is pretty much a generalist.
quotes.speaker: Emily Kramer
quotes.context: Counter to the common urge to hire specialists early, this emphasizes generalists as the best default for first marketing hires in startups.

quotes.topic_title: Pie-shaped marketers and early-stage hiring approach
quotes.text: what I tell people when you're hiring your first marketer and probably even your first several marketers, you're more want to hire generalist than specialists.
quotes.speaker: Emily Kramer
quotes.context: Clear early-stage hiring guidance: prioritize generalists for the first marketing hires before specializing.

quotes.topic_title: Pie-shaped marketers and early-stage hiring approach
quotes.text: I use this thing that I made up which is you one up higher pie shaped marketers, not pie like dessert, but pie like 3.14 where the pie symbol has two vertical lines. So like a T but it has an extra line.
quotes.speaker: Emily Kramer
quotes.context: Introduces a memorable hiring framework that extends the common T-shaped model into a more useful early-stage archetype.

quotes.topic_title: Pie-shaped marketers and early-stage hiring approach
quotes.text: And it's because you want the first marketer to be an expert in one of those three areas that I mentioned, product marketing, content marketing, growth marketing.
quotes.speaker: Emily Kramer
quotes.context: Defines the core “depth” requirement for the first marketer by anchoring it to three foundational marketing pillars.

quotes.topic_title: Pie-shaped marketers and early-stage hiring approach
quotes.text: And you want them to be proficient in another one, the second T. But you want them to be able to set strategy and know how to hire contractors across all of them.
quotes.speaker: Emily Kramer
quotes.context: Actionable hiring rubric: look for one deep spike, a second strong spike, plus the ability to orchestrate specialists via contractors.

quotes.topic_title: Pie-shaped marketers and early-stage hiring approach
quotes.text: The last thing I'll say on the pie piece is that it's really hard to find someone that's a content marketer that's also really good at growth. Like that pie shape marketer exists a lot less frequently.
quotes.speaker: Emily Kramer
quotes.context: Counterintuitive constraint for hiring: certain skill pairings (content + growth) are rarer than founders assume, shaping realistic search criteria.

quotes.topic_title: Growth PM vs growth marketing in PLG
quotes.text: In top down sales businesses it is 100% different.
quotes.speaker: Emily Kramer
quotes.context: A clear distinction that growth marketing and product growth are fundamentally different roles in top-down sales motions.

quotes.topic_title: Growth PM vs growth marketing in PLG
quotes.text: In a product led growth business, the growth marketer and the product grows sort of role or the hybrid growth role, sometimes it can be the same person depending on the skill.
quotes.speaker: Emily Kramer
quotes.context: A practical framework for PLG org design: these roles can collapse into one early on if the person spans both skill sets.

quotes.topic_title: Growth PM vs growth marketing in PLG
quotes.text: But typically the difference would be that the growth marketer is doing more of the top of funnel sort of inbound side and the product growth person is doing more once they actually get into the product, but can be collaborated with that growth marketer.
quotes.speaker: Emily Kramer
quotes.context: Defines a clean handoff boundary (pre-signup vs in-product) while emphasizing collaboration to avoid a broken funnel.

quotes.topic_title: Growth PM vs growth marketing in PLG
quotes.text: I think I want to see that they've worked on a team that's early enough where they are not siloed into their specific role.
quotes.speaker: Emily Kramer
quotes.context: Actionable hiring filter for first marketers: prioritize candidates with cross-functional exposure over narrow, siloed experience.

quotes.topic_title: Growth PM vs growth marketing in PLG
quotes.text: You don't want to go out and hire someone super senior who's only worked at a public company. That's the wrong person.
quotes.speaker: Emily Kramer
quotes.context: Counterintuitive hiring advice that warns against “big-brand” resumes for first-marketer roles at startups.

quotes.topic_title: What to look for in first product marketer
quotes.text: This can be hard to find, but I think I want to see that they've worked on a team that's early enough where they are not siloed into their specific role.
quotes.speaker: Emily Kramer
quotes.context: A practical hiring signal for first product marketers: prioritize candidates with early-stage exposure where they had to see and do more than a narrow PMM slice.

quotes.topic_title: What to look for in first product marketer
quotes.text: Also product marketer needs to know how to write.
quotes.speaker: Emily Kramer
quotes.context: Sets a clear bar for early PMM hires: writing is a core competency because they’ll function as the default copywriter early on.

quotes.topic_title: What to look for in first product marketer
quotes.text: You don't want to go out and hire someone super senior who's only worked at a public company. That's the wrong person.
quotes.speaker: Emily Kramer
quotes.context: A contrarian warning against the common “hire a big-name senior marketer” instinct for first marketing roles at startups.

quotes.topic_title: What to look for in first product marketer
quotes.text: Just because they don't understand how all the marketing works together and they don't understand how they built the foundation.
quotes.speaker: Emily Kramer
quotes.context: Explains the core failure mode of big-company-only hires: they may lack experience building the marketing system from scratch.

quotes.topic_title: What to look for in first product marketer
quotes.text: So you're really looking for most roles or most lead of function roles at startups, they need to be both strategic and of scrappy enough to get the work done.
quotes.speaker: Emily Kramer
quotes.context: A simple hiring framework for early leaders: screen for both strategy and hands-on execution ability.

quotes.topic_title: When to hire first marketer and readiness checks
quotes.text: But really, I think it's helpful to have some sort of semblance of product market fit. Maybe you're not 100% sure, but maybe you have definitely some successful customers. It's not like we're working with a design partner to build this out and we have a couple pilots. Marketing is really good at accelerating growth and doing that scale one to many.
quotes.speaker: Emily Kramer
quotes.context: A practical readiness check: hire marketing once you have early proof of PMF and need to scale one-to-many growth.

quotes.topic_title: When to hire first marketer and readiness checks
quotes.text: So if you're still in the very well spoke founder led sales, founder led marketing, like I'm doing discovery with each of these potential customers and have to modify my product for them, that kind of thing. You don't need one yet.
quotes.speaker: Emily Kramer
quotes.context: Counterintuitive guidance that founders should delay hiring marketing while still in high-touch discovery and product shaping.

quotes.topic_title: When to hire first marketer and readiness checks
quotes.text: I think you need them earlier in product growth models because you're not going to hire a salesperson then.
quotes.speaker: Emily Kramer
quotes.context: A business-model-based heuristic: PLG companies may need marketing earlier because sales hiring doesn’t come first.

quotes.topic_title: When to hire first marketer and readiness checks
quotes.text: So again, the business model affects this a lot, but usually the general rule of thumb is, if you had a marketer what would they do? And I often help people try to figure that out. What would they do and if they stepped on the gas and did all this stuff really well, would you be able to handle all those people that came in? Is it even a good time to bring all those people in to your product?
quotes.speaker: Emily Kramer
quotes.context: A concrete decision framework: define the marketer’s immediate plan and test whether the product can absorb increased demand.

quotes.topic_title: When to hire first marketer and readiness checks
quotes.text: It's just not a good use money when they're kind of just sitting on their hands. I can't spend any money on paid and we don't even have any idea what to say on the website because we're selling four different things.
quotes.speaker: Emily Kramer
quotes.context: A warning sign for premature hiring: unclear positioning and constraints prevent marketing from executing effectively.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor: Athletic Greens (AG1) read
quotes.text: I kind of like to think of it as little safety net for my nutrition in case I miss something in my diet.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A simple mental model (“safety net”) for positioning a product as insurance against gaps rather than a perfect replacement.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor: Athletic Greens (AG1) read
quotes.text: Two, they treat AG1 like a software product. Apparently they are on their 52nd iteration and they're constantly evolving it based on the latest science, research studies and internal testing that they do.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A differentiating methodology: applying software-style iteration and continuous improvement to a physical consumer product.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor: Athletic Greens (AG1) read
quotes.text: Three, it's just one easy thing that I can do every single day to take care of myself.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights the power of reducing user effort to a single repeatable daily habit to drive consistency and adoption.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor: Athletic Greens (AG1) read
quotes.text: There's no need for a million different pills and supplements to look out for your health.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A counter-positioning angle that challenges the conventional “stack more supplements” approach by emphasizing simplification.

quotes.topic_title: Brand marketing in B2B and team ownership
quotes.text: To me, brand marketing is a combination or has some of the work that happens by a product marketer and by a content and community marketer.
quotes.speaker: Emily Kramer
quotes.context: Defines a practical mental model for “brand marketing” in B2B as an overlap of PMM plus content/community rather than a separate silo.

quotes.topic_title: Brand marketing in B2B and team ownership
quotes.text: But usually in B2B, the person that kind of owns the brand is the positioning story side of brand is owned by product marketing.
quotes.speaker: Emily Kramer
quotes.context: Clarifies team ownership: in early B2B orgs, brand positioning/story often sits with product marketing.

quotes.topic_title: Brand marketing in B2B and team ownership
quotes.text: So it's a little murky at first, but eventually on B2B teams when I've grown teams plus 10 to 15 people, I'll have a brand person that is working really closely with the designers and kind of making sure that everything that we're producing on the content side of things is up to... They're acting as sort an editor there.
quotes.speaker: Emily Kramer
quotes.context: Gives a concrete scaling trigger (10–15 person team) and describes the brand role as design-adjacent editor ensuring consistency.

quotes.topic_title: Brand marketing in B2B and team ownership
quotes.text: We did a huge data study when I was at Carta and the person that kind of ran that whole initiative and the events and it was sort of a separate initiative that had a lot of different parts was my brand marketer.
quotes.speaker: Emily Kramer
quotes.context: Provides a specific example of brand marketing owning large cross-channel initiatives (data study + events) that cut across marketing.

quotes.topic_title: Product vs marketing ownership and collaboration systems
quotes.text: Because that area of I'll fill out a handoff, we talk about the marketing to sales handoff all the time on the go to market side, but there's a marketing to product handoff. And that's the handoff that's really important in PLG.
quotes.speaker: Emily Kramer
quotes.context: Introduces a practical collaboration lens for PLG teams: explicitly design and manage the marketing→product handoff like you would marketing→sales.

quotes.topic_title: Product vs marketing ownership and collaboration systems
quotes.text: So I think that product led growth is a misnomer. I think people will do anything they can possibly do not call marketing marketing.
quotes.speaker: Emily Kramer
quotes.context: Challenges the common framing of PLG by calling out how “PLG” often rebrands marketing work rather than replacing it.

quotes.topic_title: Product vs marketing ownership and collaboration systems
quotes.text: In fact, to me it means you are going to have a bigger marketing team early on because you're not going to have those sales. Sales is not communicating with customers. So I think it comes back to what are these teams typically good at? And marketing is typically good at the communication piece of one to many. That's what they're good at.
quotes.speaker: Emily Kramer
quotes.context: Actionable org-design implication: PLG can increase (not decrease) the need for early marketing capacity to replace sales-driven communication.

quotes.topic_title: Product vs marketing ownership and collaboration systems
quotes.text: But I think it's just whatever it is, make it clear where the handoff is.
quotes.speaker: Emily Kramer
quotes.context: A simple operating principle teams can apply immediately to reduce product/marketing friction: define explicit ownership boundaries and handoffs.

quotes.topic_title: Product vs marketing ownership and collaboration systems
quotes.text: But it shouldn't to me like this, let's not argue about it, we're trying to move this and here's the things that marketing is going to do and here's the things that product is going to do, and here are the areas of overlap.
quotes.speaker: Emily Kramer
quotes.context: Provides a pragmatic collaboration method: stop debating ownership in the abstract and instead document responsibilities plus overlap areas.
